DARWIN: So they are the more developed species.
EVELYN: So what do you think they're going to do with us?
DARWIN: What does any species do to its inferiors?
FITZROY: (breathless) One moment, Doctor, please. I can barely see where I am going.
DOCTOR: All right, Captain. I think we're safe now.
FITZROY: Those, those things back there were Silurians, I take it?
DOCTOR: Yes. Luckily I don't think they saw us. Did you see they were taking the passage leading up to the jail house?
FITZROY: But that means they were going to the settlement.
DOCTOR: Yes. I wonder what they want there? Hmm.
FITZROY: Oh, it's freezing.
DOCTOR: Yes, you're right. Yes, it is a bit chilly. Stay close to me. Oh, it's getting lighter up ahead.
FITZROY: These walls, they're solid ice and, Doctor!
DOCTOR: Hmm? Oh. So that's what's happened to all the missing prisoners. Of course.
FITZROY: What is this place?
DOCTOR: I should have thought that was obvious. Corpses hanging by hooks from the ceiling like so many bloated bags of grey and white mottled flesh? Doesn't it remind you of anything?
FITZROY: Of course it does. They're like carcasses in a, in a butcher's shop.
DOCTOR: Exactly. This is the Silurians' larder.
FITZROY: What do you mean?
DOCTOR: They eat people.
FITZROY: But that is monstrous, absolutely monstrous!
DOCTOR: Is it? All species prey on lesser species. That's how nature works. Just because Man doesn't happen to be the top of this particular food chain, well, that doesn't make it wrong.
FITZROY: How could you say such a thing? They're human beings, hung up there like
DOCTOR: Like cattle? To the Silurians, that's all humans are.
FITZROY: We are not. We have morality, culture. We have immortal souls. We're not just dumb animals to be butchered.
DOCTOR: As far as the Silurians are concerned, that is exactly what you are. Dumb animals, that have, unfortunately, multiplied out of control and overrun the planet.
FITZROY: But if that is true, that is inhuman.
SH'VAK: But we are not human.
FITZROY: Get back. Get back. What are you?
SH'VAK: The Doctor was right. We are the superior race. We are Silurians.
FITZROY: No!
DOCTOR: Fitzroy, no! It's no use.
FITZROY: No, no, no. I can't.
DOCTOR: Sh'vak, I must talk to you. It's terribly important.
SH'VAK: Silence. You will come with us.
LAWSON: Master, I could not hear you or speak to you. I believe the Doctor destroyed your marvels. Master, it's me, your servant, Lawson. Your loyal and obedient servant.
TULOK: Obedient servant?
LAWSON: Yes, master. I've served you well, haven't I?
TULOK: We shall see. In this container is a microscopic bacteria. Once released, it will strip your flesh from your bones. It will then spread rapidly through the air to feed on every adult ape creature in the settlement. Within an hour, you will all be dead. I want you to open the container, Lawson.
LAWSON: No. I won't. I
TULOK: You will obey. Open it.
LAWSON: But there's nothing in there. You were testing me, weren't you, master?
TULOK: The punishment for failure is death.
LAWSON: I don't understand, mast (gasps) No, what's happening to me? It burns! My hands!
TULOK: You should be grateful. Even as your body is eaten away, you assist the Silurian race. Thanks to you, the Earth will soon be ours.
DOCTOR: Sh'vak, you must listen to me. You were asking about the other Silurian colonies, whether any had survived? I know what happened.
SH'VAK: Both of you, in there.
DOCTOR: Wait. Ow!
EVELYN: Doctor. Oh, at last. I knew you'd turn up eventually.
FITZROY: Charles! And Miss Smythe. You're well?
DARWIN: Much the better for seeing you, Captain. And the Doctor. I have so many questions for you.
DOCTOR: I'm sure you do, but they will have to wait. Evelyn, Charles, have the Silurians harmed either of you at all?
EVELYN: No, I wouldn't say they. What did you call them? Silurians?
DOCTOR: Yes.
EVELYN: I wouldn't say they've been the perfect hosts but, apart from keeping us cooped up in here, they haven't done anything.
DOCTOR: That's something, at least.
DARWIN: What is it, Doctor? Fitzroy?
FITZROY: You tell them, Doctor. I cannot stomach it.
DOCTOR: The Governor of this island, Lawson, he's been imprisoning innocent people and supplying them to the Silurians.
EVELYN: We'd guessed as much. Wait, what do you mean, supplying them?
DOCTOR: Lawson has been providing the Silurians with their source of food.
DARWIN: My God.
DOCTOR: Fitzroy and I visited their deep-freeze. It was er, well-stocked.
EVELYN: You mean? That's horrible.
DOCTOR: Oh, it's going to get a good deal more horrible than that.
DARWIN: What are you saying, Doctor?
DOCTOR: Let me explain. Hundreds of thousands of years ago, the Silurians ruled the Earth. Also at this time, Man was at a very early stage in his development and was little better
DARWIN: Than a primitive ape.
DOCTOR: Exactly. Presumably at that time, the Silurians were farming those primitive ape creatures for food, in much the same way that you would farm chickens or goats. Anyway,
DOCTOR: [OC]: The Silurians had to go into hibernation, and whilst they were asleep
DARWIN: The ape creatures that were left behind began to change gradually and through process of descent through modification.
SH'VAK: These creatures believe they are the result of natural selection? They do not realise their true nature.
LOKAN: Sh'vak, should I have them slaughtered?
SH'VAK: No, Lokan. No, not yet. There is still more to be learned from the one called the Doctor. He knows about the Great Hibernation.
TANNOY: Gortal Clan report to hibernation chamber four. Gortal Clan, report.
TANNOY: 2: Temperature is reduced to twenty below freezing. I repeat, the temperature has dropped to.
SILURIAN: S'Rel Tulok, the penalty for your crimes is death. However, in recognition of your past achievements we are prepared to show you mercy. You will be banished to the Earth's surface.
SH'VAK: There is nothing I can do. I'm sorry.
TULOK: Don't let them do this. Those cowards, they dare to condemn me. And my creatures. What will happen to my creatures?
TULOK: No, no, Sh'vak. Sh'vak, don't leave me out here. Sh'vak, don't leave me out here.
SH'VAK: Tulok.
TULOK: Sh'vak, I knew you could not betray me.
SH'VAK: You saved my life once. I will never forget that. We haven't got much time. We must get to the hibernation chambers.
TULOK: The hibernation chambers? Not yet. I must know what's happened to my creatures.
SH'VAK: The genetic augmentations? Why do you care what happens to them?
SILURIAN: Release the monstrosities onto the planet's surface to join their creator. The vengeance of nature shall sweep them both away.
TULOK: The cages, they are empty. They're all empty! Argh,
SH'VAK: We are too late. They must have sent them out onto the surface.
TULOK: Oh, my creatures. (can't make it out) for the primitive beasts into sentient beings, something that is almost our equal. That is why they called them monsters. That is why they are frightened of what I have achieved. I improved their flavour, I made them breed faster, I made them resistant to disease. Our leaders were satisfied enough then. But then I made them intelligent enough to cultivate themselves. I gave them their own minds.
SH'VAK: Tulok, we must go.
TULOK: But now all my work has been destroyed. I will not forgive this.
SH'VAK: There's nothing you can do. The Triad leaders have all entered suspended animation. It's time we joined them.
TULOK: I shall have my revenge.
TULOK: Sh'vak.
SH'VAK: Tulok.
SH'VAK: How did the bacteria perform in the test?
TULOK: It was most satisfactory. The plague spread rapidly throughout the settlement. All but the new-born have now been destroyed. Sh'vak, start mass-producing the bacteria.
SH'VAK: Yes, Leader.
TULOK: We shall depart for the mainland as soon as possible. Once there, we will release the
TULOK: infection into the atmosphere. We will sweep the adult humans from the face of the Earth in a tide of blood.
SH'VAK: And the infants that remain?
TULOK: As we repopulate the planet, they will become our slaves, except of course for those we bring to the slaughter.
LOKAN: [OC]: Leader Tulok, the ape creatures. We have two more captives.
TULOK: Excellent. I have developed an appetite.
DARWIN: That's where we came from. That is the origin of our species. We are just these lizard men's cattle.
FITZROY: Charles, but what you're saying, it's beyond blasphemy.
DARWIN: What, that Man is a result not of divine providence but the struggle for survival? Oh, we assume that the abundance of nature is proof of the Lord's existence, but what if that is not so? What if our existence is just the result of blind chance?
FITZROY: What do you mean?
DARWIN: A God that did not create the world, the oceans, and animals, and the plants. A God that did not make Man. A God responsible for nothing may as well be no God at all. Do you not agree, Doctor?
EVELYN: Doctor?
DOCTOR: I don't know. But I'll tell you one thing. In the skies above us are a billion suns, each circled by their own worlds. And on those worlds, wherever there is the opportunity for life, you will find it. That is the miracle. Life endures. It thrives. It defeats every adversity. It creates order out of chaos. Above us is a universe full of wonder, and we are just
TULOK: You humans, you did not evolve from apes by accident. You are the product of my genetic engineering. I created you. I am your God.

elements.text: [Part Four]
What in the name of all that's
You are my creatures. I raised you up from amongst the animals. You belong to me.
Never!
You, the humans from the marine transport, come with me.
No. We are not your creatures.
You cannot resist. Your minds are but clay in my hands. You will obey me.
Silurian third eye weapon, cries of pain.
You are now under my direction. Follow.
+ FITZROY: Yes, master.
Door closes.
Doctor, where's it taking them?
I'm not sure.
What did that creature mean when it said we are the product of its genetic engineering?
It's perfectly straight forward. To them, humans are just cattle that they have altered to be more economic, more productive.
Like making wheat resistant to frost and insects?
Exactly, except in this case they not only improve their cattle physically but mentally. They took Australopithecus apes and made Homo Sapiens. You, Evelyn.
So that's why there isn't a missing link. There never was one.
Mmm hmm.
We were just concocted in a test tube somewhere.

The Silurians have upset the delicate balance of nature. Just as a modified crop can overrun the countryside, decimating all rival species, the same thing happened with humanity. That's the trouble with genetically modified foods. You turn your back for five minutes, and they've taken over the world.
So what is it the Silurians intend to do?
Suppose you woke up to discover that your house was overrun by vermin. What would you do?
I'd put down some pesticide.
Ah ha.
Oh. I see.
Quite.
So what are we going to do? Sitting her talking isn't
[OC]: Going to get us out of here.
[OC]: You would be surprised.
Door opens.
Sh'vak, you have synthesised the bacteria as instructed?
Yes, Leader. These canisters contain sufficient quantity of the micro-organism to eradicate a whole continent of the ape creatures.
They must be loaded into the submersible at once. Ape creatures.
+ FITZROY: Yes?
You will take these canisters to the submersible bay. Lift them, one each. I will guide you.
+ FITZROY: Yes, master.
Door closes.
[OC]: The hibernation chamber? You mean that big sort of crypt with all the stone coffins?
[OC]: Yes. The device that was supposed to reanimate the Silurians from their dormant state, the timing mechanism had been disconnected.
[OC]: What do you mean, disconnected?
[OC]: It had been fixed so that when the activation signal came through, the Silurians wouldn't wake up, throughout the globe.
[OC]: But who'd do such a thing?

[OC]: Well, if I could show you the control unit, you'd be able to see the sabotage for yourself. You'd be able to see that someone had rigged the resuscitation linkages so that only a few dozen Silurians and their pet Myrka would survive, so that they alone would remain as the rest of their race were condemned to their graves.
Tulok.
Ape creatures, load the canisters into the submersible here.
Yes, master.
Clang, clatter.
The submersible is primed and ready to be launched.
That is good. Ape creatures, return to the laboratory and fetch the remaining canisters.
Well, it's all very fascinating, you telling me all this, but I still can't see how it's going to help up get out of here.
Have a little faith. (sotto) Our conversation is being monitored.
(sotto) You mean the cell is bugged? Where?
(sotto) That's not important.
(sotto) But how can you be so sure
Door opens.
Ah.
Doctor.
Sh'vak.
All right.
You were listening, then, I take it?
Doctor, I have visited the hibernation centre and examined the control unit. You were correct.
I'm very sorry.
Tulok. So that was his revenge. To deny the Silurians their day of awakening. To deny them the world. All part of his retribution.
You know why he did it?

Our leaders wanted to put an end to his experiments. He had broken the most sacred tenets of Silurian law by tampering with creation. Our leaders sentenced him to be banished to the surface of the planet with his creatures, but
But?
But I saved him.
Oh, I see.
Because of me, Tulok has destroyed an entire race. He has committed the ultimate evil. He has betrayed the natural order.
The natural order?
The belief that is the foundation of Silurian culture, that life exists only as nature's servant.
Tulok thought himself its master. But his arrogance is not his own. It is that of the whole Silurian race. Through him, we destroyed our world. We destroyed ourselves. We have no claim to the Earth.
You mean you're prepared to let humanity have the planet?
They deserve the chance to survive. We had our time and failed. Let humanity further (uncertain) it.
Sh'vak, it's not too late. You can make amends, you know.
I thought I would show him compassion, and how did he repay me?
You only did what you thought was right. Compassion is nothing to regret.
There is only one way I can redeem the memory of the Silurian race. Tulok must be stopped.
What does he intend to do?
We have developed an airborne bacteria that will wipe out all humans.
What?
Our submersible is about to leave for the mainland, and then Tulok is going to release the bacteria into the atmosphere.
All of the canisters have been loaded?
Yes, Leader.
Excellent. Have the two ape creatures taken back to the enclosure, Lokan.
Yes, Leader.
Wait. Sh'vak. Where is Primary Scientist Sh'vak?
I do not know.
She should be here, unless. Delay the launch. I must return to the bunker.
Sh'vak, get us out of here. If what you say is true, we don't have much time left.
Tulok has betrayed me. He will die.
No, I can help you.
I must go.
No, wait, wait.
Door closes.
Oh.
Right. So much for Sh'vak helping us. What do we do now?
I'd rather been banking being on the other side of that door. Oh, I hope Sh'vak, well, I hope she doesn't try anything rash. She's our only chance of getting out of here in one piece.
What about Charles and Captain Fitzroy? You don't think they
Door opens.
You, ape creatures, in.
+ FITZROY: Yes, master.
Thank goodness they're all right.
I wouldn't be so certain.
What?
Door closes.

Well, they're in a state of catalepsy. A form of post-psychic shock. The Silurians have been controlling them. They have a telepathic link into the primal mind. They can operate humans like, well, marionettes.
Like Lawson, you mean? You're saying they're under some sort of hypnosis.

Fortunately, in the hands of an expert it's reversible. Charles? Fitzroy? Concentrate on my voice. On the count of three, you will wake up, free from the Silurians' influence. One, two, three. Wake up. (snaps fingers)
Oh, what's happened?
The lizard creature, it claimed to be God.
You don't remember anything else?
It is a blur. The Silurian was declaring that it created Man. Is this true, Doctor?
Well, Charles, the Silurians used their great scientific knowledge to domestic and adapt a form of primitive ape. Your ancestors are the products of Tulok's experimentation.
And to think I thought Man was the product of the descent with modification. How could I be so mistaken, so wilfully blind to imagine
No, no, you weren't wrong, Charles. Your theory still stands.
(sotto) Doctor.
Hmm?
(sotto) What was it you told me about prompting?
Oh, er. (sotto) It's too important.

Doctor, if what you claim is true, if these Silurian creatures had domination over the Earth, why did they not leave fossils? We have petrified relics of land mammals, but we have nothing akin to these creatures at all.

Monkton's Theorum. Any reasonably intelligent lifeform is not going to leave a fossil. Only the most stupid creatures will be preserved because they are the only ones who are going to allow themselves to get trapped in tar pits.
But why aren't there any other remains? You said these creatures once had vast cities.

That was over a million years ago. Tell me, how many of your buildings would last that long? Your oldest structures are barely ten millennia old, never mind a hundred times that. Ask yourself, what will be humanity's legacy, hmm? There won't be any great monuments or fossils or graves, or even one footprint. Not a single trace will remain. It will be as if mankind had never existed.
Oh, don't say that. That's horrible.
You should see it as I see it. That's history. All of human life, just a brief candle in the darkness.
Door slides open.
Ah, Sh'vak. At last.
Tulok, I want to talk to you.
Door slides shut.
About the hibernation chambers.
I am not interested.
The control unit, it was sabotaged.
Who told you this, the Doctor?
I saved your life once. You owe me the truth.
I have not forgotten, but I tell you it was an accident.
I've been to the hibernation chambers and examined the unit for myself. The timing mechanism had been deliberately disconnected.

They were weak. I had to do it. The cowards, they deserved to die. They dared to condemn me. They treated me like a criminal. They wanted me dead. But now the world is mine, and in this brave new Earth I will be as a god, the Creator Supreme. The world will be ours once more, Sh'vak.
You dishonour our memory. You have betrayed everything we hold sacred. Better the humans have the Earth, than an Earth ruled by you. You have destroyed our entire race. You have destroyed our world.
Silurian third eye weapon.
Sh'vak, what are you doing? No!
You are evil. You must die.
You think you can kill me so easily, Sh'vak? You are foolish. Your mental powers are no equal to mine.
I will stop you. I must.
I have your mind in my grasp.
No.
You always were pathetic, Sh'vak. So easily manipulated. But now you are not needed.
Two mind weapons battling.
Die. Die. Die!
Sh'vak gurgles.
These creatures had some sort of mental hold over us? I can scarcely believe it.
They can render us unconscious without recourse to physical action, or coerce us into action. We are but animals of the lowest grade to them.
Exactly. To the Silurians, you are no different from those easily dominated savages they harvested all those years ago.
But modern man is quite distinct from the savage. They are creatures of instinct and superstition. We are civilised.
Civilised? When you treat your fellow man as an inferior being?

No, but Doctor, perhaps Captain Fitzroy has a point. If we are agreed upon the hypothesis of natural selection, might not Man have changed in some small measure since the Silurians ruled the Earth? Perhaps they do not realise it, but perhaps we are not quite the same species. Perhaps we are
now endowed with a higher intelligence and self-will.
You mean we might have developed a resistance to their mental control?
Precisely.
I think you may be on to something, Charles.
And how does this aid us?
Perhaps they aren't quite as irresistible as they think they are. Maybe under certain circumstances Man can repel the will of the Silurians.
You mean, we might be able to defeat them?
And if they don't realise that, or even better
[OC]: If that is precisely what they're afraid of
Afraid? If humanity has degraded, I will recreate a new species in its place. I hold that power.
[OC]: Leader Tulok, the submersible
I will join you on board shortly, Lokan. Now I want the ape creatures slaughtered immediately.
[OC]: Yes, Leader.
And so it begins, the purification of the Earth, the extermination that is good.
But we still have to get out of this enclosure.
Oh, I'm open to any suggestions. No?
Remember that thing where one of us pretends to be ill, and then when the guards rush in
No.
No. You're supposed to be the one with all the clever ideas.
Well, I was hoping that Sh'vak would be able to help us, but
Sh'vak is the one who consented to aid us?

[OC]: Ape creatures, your attention. I am about to depart in my submersible craft, where I intend to rid this planet of your degenerate bloodline. Doctor, I am aware of your conspiracy against me. It has failed.
What?
[OC]: Sh'vak is dead.
Oh, now we're in serious trouble.
You mean we weren't in serious trouble before? And there was me worrying.
[OC]: I have sent a Silurian to put you all to death. Your bodies will be consumed on our return. Die well, Doctor. I feel I will particularly enjoy the taste of your corpse.
And just what are you implying by that, exactly, eh?
Oh, come on, Doctor. We have to do something.
I'm afraid it's already too late. Listen. They're on their way.
This is it. We must try to overpower them. It's our only chance. Charles, ready?
Door opens.
No, wait!
Doctor.
Sh'vak! But I thought. Tulok said you were dead.
Tulok overcame me, but perhaps I am not as weak-willed as he thought. He crushed my mind but I held on, alive.
But what about the Silurian despatched to kill us?
He is no longer a threat.
You mean, you mean you're with us, lizard?
Yes
Good. Well, I'm glad we got all that sorted out. Now, we haven't got much time, if it's not already too late. We have to stop Tulok leaving at all costs. I think, the control room.
And what do you intend to do when we get there?
Oh, er, well, by then I'll probably have thought of something terribly ingenious. Come on!
Leader Tulok.
Our craft is ready to leave?
Yes, Leader. All systems checked and initiated. Power output at parameter eight.
Then we must go immediately. Set a course for the mainland.
[OC]: Er, hello there.
What?
[OC]: Silurian bunker calling submersible. Bunker calling submersible. Can you read me?
Over.
What is this?
[OC]: Ah, there you are, Tulok, old chap. Hope you're keeping well. So glad I caught you before you had to rush off. Over.
Doctor, you, you are in the bunker control room.
[OC]: That's right. Can't say I care for the dcor, but as control rooms go, I've seen worse.
[OC]: Over.
[OC]: Oops, sorry. Over.
How did you escape from the enclosure? I sent a Silurian
[OC]: Oh, him. You know, you Silurians aren't all that invincible. It's quite easy to resist your telepathic attacks if you put your mind to it. Human beings are stronger than they look. Over.
You lie! You are inferior. I made you inferior.

[OC]: Well, we managed to escape and get into your control room, didn't we? Speaking of which, these hydrogen fusion reactors of yours, I find they overload so easily, don't they? All it takes is a few minor adjustments and you're minutes away from a major explosion.
What?
[OC]: Oh, I want to meet you for a chat. Face to face. That's all. You know where to find me. You've got about fifteen minutes before this place goes up? Over and out.
Leader, all systems are ready. Shall we leave?
No. Check the energy sensors.
Energy sensors detect a power surge in bunker reactor. If it continues at the current rate
So the Doctor was telling the truth. Our departure can wait. He will die, even if it must be by my own hand. You will remain here on guard. We will see how well he resists the might of the Silurians.
Alarm sounding.
Right, so this Tulok fellow is on his way up. Now what, Doctor?
Well, we'll have to try and hold him off somehow, won't we. You, me, and young Charles here.
You really have overloaded the reactors?
Oh yes, certainly. In fourteen minutes from now, we'll be blown sky-high.
Well, in that case, shouldn't we be getting out of here?
No. No, we can't do that. We have to stay here. And whilst we're busy here, I want you to take this device and place it inside the submersible. Make sure it's well hidden.
Doctor.
Sorry, what?
Me? Go down there? Alone? Please tell me you're joking.
I am deadly serious. Look, we'll be dealing with Tulok here, and keeping him out of your way, so you should be perfectly safe.
I don't like the use of the word should.
So it's just us three against Tulok? Do you sincerely believe we stand a chance of stopping him?
Well, always assuming that Charles was right.
I was right?
That man has adapted over the last hundred thousand years, that you are no longer as susceptible to the Silurian psychic control as you once were.
But Lawson.

Oh, people who want to be lead always will be. Perhaps he had a domineering mother. Anyway, we three with enough will-power should be able to, well, at least keep him busy for a while. For thirteen minutes or so.
Just how do we do this?
You should concentrate your minds. Keep all your thoughts fixed on something you believe in.
Doctor.
Ah, Sh'vak. Now, you know what you have to do.
I understand. (receding) I must remain out of sight.
Doctor, it's Tulok. He's coming.
Right, everyone ready. Evelyn, you must go, now.
All right. Good luck.
Good luck.
Door opens and closes.
Fitzroy, Charles, remember what I said. Concentrate on something you believe in totally.
Door opens.
Doctor.
Tulok. Delighted you could make it.
Door closes.
You've already met my friends, Charles Darwin, Captain Fitzroy, haven't you?
You have overloaded the hydrogen reactor. Move away from the controls now.

No, I don't think so. And before you attack us, I wouldn't advise using your third eye in here. A couple of inches out and the energy will destroy the reactor override, which I don't need to tell you will immediately precipitate a fission meltdown, or in other words, a very, very big explosion.
You, stop the power transfer.
And if you take one step closer, I'm afraid I'll have no choice but to press this button here, which will also immediately precipitate a fission meltdown.
Stop the power transfer. I command you to stop it.
No. No. You see, your telepathy won't work on us. We can beat you.
No. You ape creatures, I order you, kill the Doctor.
Charles, Fitzroy, now! Concentrate now! You can resist.
Sounds of effort.
No, no.
Hold on, Charles. Keep a grip on your mind. Remember what I said, Charles.
I can't.
Your minds, your minds are mine.
No! You're wrong!
You cannot resist me.
We can resist you.
I can't fight it much longer, Doctor. He's too strong.
You must hold on, Charles.
It's inside my head. Our Father, who art in Heaven, hallowed be thy name.
Don't let him control you. Concentrate now!
Thy will be done on Earth as it is in Heaven.
Something you believe in. Come on, Charles.
I command you, kill the Doctor.
Forgive us our trespasses.
No. Come on, Fitzroy. Hold on. Hold on! Hold on!
Kill the Doctor. Kill him! Kill!
So this is what the inside of a Silurian submarine looks like. Very nice, I must say. Now, where would be a good place to hide this. Ah, perfect.
Door creaks open then closed again.
That was easy. I'm surprised these Silurians didn't think to leave someone on guard. Still, they'll never think of looking in there.
Ape creature, what are you doing in here?
Kill the Doctor.
Hold on. Think what you believe in. What you truly believe in.
You must kill the Doctor.
Our Saviour. No.
Go on, Charles.
No, I don't. I believe
Yes?
Master.
I believe in descent through modification!
Yes, Charles!
I believe in natural selection.
Yes!
It is no good, Doctor. You cannot fight me.
No. No, you're wrong. Man is not the primitive creature you once knew. Evolution has run its course. Humanity is no longer your servant.
You lie. I am your master.
I believe! I believe Man has changed. Man is the master of his own destiny! You do not control us.
No! You bow down before me. I am your god.
You are not our god. There is no god! We are the result of natural selection. We don't owe our existences to you!
You, Fitzroy, stop him.
No, no. No, I don't obey.
What is happening?

I obey, master.

That's what I believe they call a close thing.

Leader Tulok, you defeated the ape creatures?

Doctor.

Yes, Leader.
Roar.

Boom!

Have I tried pressing the button? Of course I've tried pressing the button.

Allow me.

Doctor, it's getting hotter.
Multiple explosions.
It's so peaceful. The birds, the sunset. You'd think that nothing had happened.

Doctor, over there. That column of smoke.

Gone.
We'll never see or hear of them again.

Alfred Wallace?

Yes. Yes. Hmm. Alfred Wallace. You know, that reminds me. I always meant to pop back and give him some moral support.
No, Doctor.
No?
No.
Mmm, perhaps you're right, Evelyn. Perhaps you're right.
